The lunar module ascent engines were hypergolic. They used reactants that ignite on contact with one another. I can't imagine a better choice of reactants than hypergolics for these engines .... it eliminates an entire layer of complexity from the system: ignition components. So ... less of a life or death situation that stated here. The components WILL ignite unless the respective valves fail to open, but nice presentation!

comment_text: 0:07 - We get it. You vape.

Back in WWII, the Germans tested every single part of their rockets and improved it until it all worked out fine. This procedure isn't that uncommon, when you consider that one tiny, cheap part can ruin one expensive rocket including the payload. So they have to ensure that everything works out well. Even the life's of astronauts depend on the success of all parts of the rockets.
Nice work in collecting data... But the presentation sucks..

As fortune would have it, I was there for the F9H static test firing. Alas, I didn’t get a heads-up, so I was in the Saturn V building at the time, so I didn’t get to SEE it... but I definitely HEARD it! 🚀

Happened to wonder if you were filming some of those early shots, and glanced up and saw K. Scott Piel. He happens to be the author of one of the best and most intricate add-on modifications for World of Warcraft I have ever seen, and had a loyal fan base himself, and just last year ended maintenance of that application. I was disheartened, because without him it hasn't been updated to keep up with game updates, and playing the game without is like living in this day and age without a cellphone. I'm glad to see what he's moved on to. Amazing coincidence.

It's a usual procedure to do a static fire with a new and/or modified launch vehicle, as with Orbital Sciences' (now Orbital ATK's) Antares. But doing so many static fires is highly unusual. I can easily see it causing needless wear on the engine components, leading to shorter lifespans (particularly since they want to re-use the engines).

Once again Musk and his company choose not to do the sensible thing.

Jesus, I saw the steam and thought that was it.  Then when it really kicked off, I nearly jumped out of my seat...

Thanks for clearing up the staggered information. I actually commented on another video and said that it appears more like 3 engines per booster every 250 milliseconds or so. Then full test throttle for about 4 seconds and then a stagger down. It was clearly only about a 5 second fire test. Sure the steam cloud was there for a much longer period but the actual evidence of thrust was not, not to my eyes and ears. I turned up the speakers as loud as I could too. Lol, I would love to be able to attend the launch. I have not been this excited since visiting in person a live shuttle landing and transportation on top of a 747.
